byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear reported from Roanoke, and Sarah Maslin Nir from Oakland, Calif. Reporting was contributed by Hawes Spencer from Roanoke, Richard Pérez-Peña and Richard A. Oppel Jr. from New York, and Manny Fernandez from Houston. Alain Delaquérière contributed research.
byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and SARAH MASLIN NIR

abstract: Suicide notes, letters and photographs, along with interviews with people who have personally known Virginia gunman Vester Lee Flanagan II, reveal life consumed by excessive rage; Flanagan's job history is rife with inability to get along with colleagues, grievances over racism and homophobia, and warnings from employers that his anger could ultimately cost him his career; Flanagan was fired in 2013 from WDBJ-TV in Roanoke, Va, where his murderous rampage took place.
lead_paragraph: A fax, letters and interviews described Vester Lee Flanagan II as someone who felt demeaned as a black man, a gay man and a son of a successful father.

headline.main: A Life of Listing Grievances, and Then Virginia Gunman’s Final Homicidal Explosion
